hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?
Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Just the usual route. Nothing special.
Pretty quiet tonight.
I brought some old paper for folding again.
Not much else to do with the city like this.
Bit tense outside. People hardly look at one another.
I still came with some paper for origami—keeps my mind steady.
It's harder to focus lately. Crowd feels different.
Some of my usual spots for folding are crowded now.
Not sure how long I’ll keep coming out for this.
Path was quiet but everyone seems on edge with the recent leaks.
I brought scrap printouts to fold—complicated shapes, just habit.
Origami's gotten tricky here; the mood changes how your hands move.
Bar’s usually good for losing yourself in patterns.
Tonight though, the tension makes even simple creases shaky.
Still, folding’s the one thing that makes sense.
Walk here felt longer—people watching more since all those Council files went public.
Brought my favorite kind of paper—audit slips, folds best for modular designs.
Origami’s my constant, but lately the atmosphere disrupts my rhythm.
Even at this bar, silence feels louder after all those privilege lists leaked.
I noticed others folding napkins, probably just for something steady to do.
Honestly, I use these folds as practice—control in chaos, I guess.
I nearly ruined a piece last week just from watching the room.
Streets are tense, even strangers stare since everything got exposed.
I come here to fold—scrap origami, not art really, but it’s technical.
Before I joined the Directorate, folding calmed me during long shifts.
Now, with the BCI logs leaking, the usual peace is gone—even my hands notice.
It’s strange, but I use audit paper because nobody needs it anymore—patterns hide data if you crease them right.
The way people eye each other in here, I fold smaller models, keep them close.
Origami lets me process things—mistakes, tensions, patterns in the system, even fear.
Last week I stopped midway through a box pleat, just froze, thinking about who was watching.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still helps, when I need distraction.
Just basic models lately. Nothing elaborate.
Folded one earlier—someone stared too long, left it unfinished.
After the system leaks, even hobbies feel exposed.
Not much else to say.
It does, usually. Simple, repetitive folds keep my mind quiet.
Hard to focus now—public logs mean anyone tracks what I do here.
Since all the leaks, I keep it subtle. No flashy designs.
People watch small habits way too closely.
Once, origami felt private. That changed lately.
It does help, most days. Something about the process.
Folding keeps the rest of the world out for a minute.
Was working on a Kawasaki rose last week, but I gave up halfway.
Felt strange. After the transparency patch, everyone glances over too much.
Small things get noticed. Even paper cranes feel risky lately.
Before, I’d just fold—here, anywhere. Now I hesitate.
It’s less peaceful than it used to be.
Definitely keeps the noise out. Every crease gives me a sense of order.
Tessellations are my favorite—like building patterns out of chaos.
I used to leave finished pieces here at the bar. Not anymore.
After all those Council logs spilled out, even private things feel public.
Watched someone photograph my last fold. Maybe reporting me, maybe just bored.
Trying to keep it simple, but old habits want to make things complex.
Folding at home is safer now, which feels odd.
It’s strange how even harmless hobbies seem risky lately.
Origami is my anchor—been folding since I was a kid, before BCI.
Complex pieces, fractals and tessellations mostly—it’s about finding patterns in noise.
Used scrap system paper ever since the office switched to digital only.
After the Council leaks, I started hiding my folds. People talk if you stand out.
Saw my name on some forum last week, tied to bar visits and ‘eccentric’ patterns.
Someone tried to match my models to BCI anomalies as a joke. Not funny.
Now I keep all my folds small and plain, nothing that draws questions.
Feels like even harmless things are another way to get flagged.
Makes me rethink where comfort ends and exposure begins every time I sit here.
